Economic Times WhatsApp channel
)

headline: Cosmetic battle intensifies as Birla & Ambani vie for space on your dressing table
content:
As dozens of
beauty brands
have popped in the past few years and global companies too begin to find promise in India, India's retail giants are betting big on the beauty and personal care segment. They are launching their own beauty businesses as well as snapping up smaller brands which pitchforked into prominence through e-commerce.
Ananya Birla
, daughter of billionaire Kumar Mangalam Birla, on Wednesday announced entry into the fast-growing beauty and cosmetics space with the launch of a new venture. The 30-year-old Birla, who launched a microlending venture at 17 and also sits on the board of the $62-billion
Aditya Birla Group
's apex strategic body, will come out with a range of beauty and personal care brands nationally through 2025, a statement said.
Ananya's company, Birla Cosmetics, will launch the beauty and personal care brands this year. The move will put her in direct competition with another billionaire daughter,
Isha Ambani
, of
Reliance
Industries chairman
Mukesh Ambani
. Isha heads the beauty and lifestyle segments at Reliance. In Feb 2023, Reliance launched Tira, a platform that sells makeup, skincare, haircare and fragrances. The Birla venture will also be competing with other biggies such as Tata, HUL and L'Oreal. The Tata Group runs its beauty business called Tata Cliq Palette.
Also Read:
Kumar Mangalam Birla's daughter Ananya announces new beauty and cosmetics venture
A company statement said rising disposable incomes, deeper e-commerce penetration and growing openness among consumers are leading India's beauty. Personal care market is expected to grow at 10-11 per cent annually and the sector is expected to be a USD 34 billion opportunity by 2028.
Live Events
You Might Also Like:
Gen Z expands a new battlefield for retail giants
The great Indian beauty boom
The Indian beauty and personal care market is poised to reach $34 billion by 2028, up from $21 billion now, driven by a surge in online penetration and a growing preference for high-quality, premium beauty products, according to a report by
Nykaa
and consulting firm Redseer. The online channel, as the fastest-growing segment, is expected to expand at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of approximately 25%, while the organised offline channel is anticipated to grow at 14%.
The ‘Nykaa Beauty Trends Report’, released a few months ago, noted that rising discretionary spending, fuelled by increased disposable income, expanded e-commerce access, and product innovation, are some of the other key trends driving momentum in this sector. Rising aspirations and higher incomes among Indian consumers will propel the market for premium beauty, expected to reach $3-3.2 billion by 2028, it said. Further, it highlighted a notable shift in consumer demand from personal care to beauty products in India, comprising skincare, makeup, haircare and fragrance categories.
A report by Redseer Strategy Consultants and Peak XV estimated last year that India’s beauty and personal care market will expand the fastest among comparable countries by size. The compounded growth rate is projected to be 10% between 2022 and 2027, which will take the market to $30 billion. India, expected to account for nearly 5% of the global growth opportunity, has a per capita category spending of $14, lower than China ($38) and a fraction of the US ($313). That is the definition of a big opportunity. For L’Oréal SA and Shiseido, two of the world’s largest cosmetics companies, India is a key growth driver.
The beauty segment is shifting fast
India's expanding e-commerce sector has led to democratisation of the market and explosion of brands which is truer for the beauty and personal care segment. As e-commerce removed the high entry barriers which existed in offline retail and Gen Z opened up to experiment with new products as well as sought more personalised ones, India witnessed an explosion of beauty and personal care brands.
You Might Also Like:
Hindustan Unilever acquires 90.5% stake in beauty brand Minimalist at Rs 2,955 crore valuation
“Online platforms have become the preferred channel for purchasing luxury beauty products, with growth nearly double that of offline channels.,” Roosevelt Dsouza, head of customer success, FMCG, NielsenIQ India, has told ET. “This shift is driven by unique product offerings from small and mid-sized manufacturers, particularly on e-commerce platforms.”
The sudden growth in the number of e-commerce brands has led to new-age brands facing challenges on scaling up beyond a point or crumbling under the pressure to turn profitable. Many brands are now jumping onto the
quick commerce
-platform to tide over these challenges. However, consolidation has also begun in the sector as big brands have realised the power of personal connect with the consumer that small brands enjoy.
Recently, HUL, India’s largest FMCG company, announced the acquisition of a 90.5% stake in Jaipur-based direct-to-consumer (D2C) beauty brand Minimalist. The deal values Minimalist at a pre-money enterprise value of Rs 2,955 crore.
A leader in mass market brands, HUL is trying to capture growing demand for niche, premium beauty brands. This acquisition underscores HUL’s focus on premium, high-margin segments, aligning with parent company Unilever’s global strategy to tap into low-penetration categories. HUL has been reorganizing its beauty and personal care (BPC) division to sharpen its focus on premium offerings. Currently, this division contributes nearly a fifth of the company’s revenue and about a third of its profits. Industry executives have told ET that various brands are looking at such options, but those conversations are in early stages. India’s beauty market is becoming increasingly competitive, with focused brands like L’Oréal, Mama Earth, and Nykaa collectively holding 33% market share. This share is expected to grow to 42% by 2027, while traditional players like HUL and Procter & Gamble could see their share drop by 900 basis points to 58%, according to a report by Redseer Strategy Consultants and Peak XV Partners.
You Might Also Like:
India beauty and personal care market to touch $34 billion by 2028: report
The vast promise of the beauty and personal care business became apparent when in 2023 the fast-growing market attracted India's largest retailer Reliance Retail Limited, which launched its omni-channel beauty platform Tira, after the sudden rise of new-age brands Nykaa and Myntra. Now yet another Indian conglomerate is ready to bet on this segment. With Ananya Birla's venture, India will have two young entreprenuers from India's leading business families competing in the same space.

Economic Times WhatsApp channel
)

headline: 27 new foreign retail brands enter India in 2024 amid rising consumer demand for luxury items
content:
New Delhi: As many as 27 new foreign retail brands entered India during 2024, almost double from the preceding year, to establish their presence in the Indian market and meet growing consumer demand for luxury items, according to JLL. Real estate consultant
JLL India
highlighted that in 2024, 27 new brands of international origin entered India, nearly doubling from 14 in 2023.
"In the past four years, 60 retailers of international origin have forayed in the country to cater to Indian consumers perpetual preference for global brands," it said.
Beauty, cosmetics and wellness; footwear, bags and accessories; and fashion and apparel were the top three retailer categories to set retail footprint in the country in 2024.
"India has attracted significant attention from international retailers, who have steadily increased their efforts to establish a presence in the country over the past four years," said Rahul Arora, Head (Office Leasing & Retail Services), and Senior Managing Director - Karnataka, Kerala, India, JLL.
Last year, 27 international brands entered the Indian market, with 56 per cent originating from the EMEA (Europe, the Middle East and Africa) region. French and Italian retailers, in particular, made notable inroads.
Live Events
"Delhi-NCR emerged as the preferred location for over half of these international retailers to open their inaugural stores, followed by Mumbai. The luxury retail sector maintained its strong momentum, with high-end brands leasing about 1,90,000 square feet of space in 2024," Arora said.
Luxury retailers continue to show keen interest in expanding their footprint in India, primarily within the fashion and apparel segment, which accounted for nearly half of the total luxury space leased during the year.
Commenting on the Indian retail real estate segment, Paras Buildtech COO Kunal Rishi said, "India's retail landscape is evolving rapidly. The influx of international brands, coupled with the expansion plans of domestic brands, has led to a surge in demand for high-quality retail spaces in prime locations."
This trend is further supported by rising urbanisation, increasing disposable income, and evolving shopping preferences, making India one of the most dynamic retail markets globally, he added.
Akash Nagpal, VP-leasing, Trehan Iris, said, "Delhi-NCR remains a top market for retail space, driven by a surge in demand and the continued influx of international brands."
In 2025, he said the Delhi-NCR is projected to add over 2 million square feet of retail space 2023 levels, further strengthening its appeal to both local and international retailers.

Economic Times WhatsApp channel
)

headline: Luxury shopping expands in India's small towns as e-commerce grows
content:
Smaller Indian cities are driving significant growth in luxury shopping, thanks to the increased access provided by online platforms. A report by
Tata Cliq Luxury
reveals that towns like
Botad
in Gujarat and Asansol in West Bengal are seeing a surge in purchases of high-end footwear, watches, clothing, and accessories. This trend marks a shift away from the traditional concentration of luxury shopping in major metropolitan areas like Mumbai, Delhi, and Bengaluru.
“Luxury is no longer the domain of high net-worth individuals. Customers from tier-2 and 3 towns and new geographies within the metros are driving a radical reboot of the industry,” analysts noted. The report highlights the growing influence of the "Henry" (high earners, not rich yet) consumer group. This segment consists of working professionals with rising incomes who are increasingly interested in luxury goods and experiences.
Tata Cliq Luxury, which generates 55% of its sales from non-metro areas such as Panchkula and Mysore, confirms this trend. “This cohort is the working population that is earning well and actively seeking out luxury experiences and goods,” said Gopal Asthana, CEO at Tata Cliq Luxury. He added, “These consumers have propelled big jumps in the sales of beauty, accessories, apparel and footwear, and their order value is comparable to those of metro consumers.” Industry experts observe that the customer base for luxury goods is evolving from established wealthy individuals to include professionals in smaller cities.
Luxury brands, including international names like Bvlgari, are embracing online platforms to reach these new markets in India. E-commerce sites like Ajio Luxe are helping brands overcome the limitations of physical store availability in smaller towns. The report also reveals rising demand for luxury items beyond fashion and jewelry, extending to categories like art, fueled in part by
social media
.
Unlike traditional luxury shoppers, these new customers are more informed and conduct research before buying. “In the digital age, they aren't willing to be mere recipients of a brand's offerings. Instead, they are leveraging knowledge - available via social media, websites and customer reviews to assess their choices,” industry experts explained. Data from Tata Cliq Luxury shows that customers typically browse six to seven brands before making a purchase, regardless of the product category.

headline: Shein India data to remain here, will sell products manufactured by Reliance Retail arm
content:
The new
Shein India
app, which went live last Friday, has products which are manufactured, marketed and sold only by
Nextgen Fast Fashion
, a fully owned subsidiary of
Reliance Retail
Ventures Ltd. Nextgen manufactures these products on the
Shein
India platform through a wide network of Indian manufacturers, in which most of which are MSMEs (micro, small and medium enterprises), according to an industry insider.
Shein has re-entered the Indian market almost five years after its ban through the country's leading retailer Reliance Retail. The new Shein Platform is built and hosted in India and its ownership and control will always remain with Reliance Retail, he said.
Shein India Fast Fashion App from Reliance Retail currently has over 10,000 downloads on Google's Play Store and is ranked among the top 10 among peers on Apple's store.
There is no equity ownership of Shein in the Indian company and app Shein India has been developed by Reliance Retail and is hosted in the country.
The newly launched platforms have no links with the now in-operational Shein app and the former website (Shein.in) which were previously managed and operated directly by Shein, he said.
Live Events
Further, the platform will be hosted on infrastructure in India and all platform data will remain in India. Shein will not have any access to, or rights, over such data, the industry insiders informed.
Reliance Retail is now working with Shein to develop a completely localised model for digitising the supply chain of Indian MSMEs and factories, creating jobs and enhancing the competitiveness of the
Indian textile sector
globally.
Moreover, Nextgen is also scaling up the network of Indian manufacturers so that India can become a supply source for Shein's global operations in future. This will also help to create substantial export opportunities for Indian MSME garment manufacturers, he said.
Shein was one of the apps that was banned by the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology in June 2020 after the escalation of tensions with China.
Almost three years after getting banned in India, Shein signed a partnership in 2023 with Reliance Retail, led by
Isha Ambani
, the daughter of billionaire Mukesh Ambani.
Reliance Retail Ventures Ltd (RRVL), through its subsidiary RRL (Reliance Retail Ltd), had entered into a technology agreement with Roadget Business Pte Ltd, which owns Shein, to develop an indigenous e-commerce retail platform.
In December last year, the government informed the Lok Sabha that the sale of branded products from Shein was not banned, though its app was blocked.
This platform is intended to create a network of local manufacturers and suppliers who will manufacture products under the brand Shein and sell them domestically and globally, Commerce & Industry Minister Piyush Goyal had said in a written reply.
The Ministry of Textiles consulted with the Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY), which in turn consulted the Ministry of Home Affairs, and conveyed no objection to the proposal of RRVL, he added.
"The licence agreement covered the protection that ownership and control of the platform will always remain with RRVL through its wholly owned subsidiary," Goyal said, adding, "As per the agreement, at all times, the platform will be hosted on infrastructure in India and all platform data will remain in India with Shein having no access to, or rights over, such data".
The agreement requires consenting parties to follow Indian laws and ensure localisation of infrastructure and platform data, Goyal added.
Established in 2008, Shein is known for its affordable pricing and is popular among millennials for its trendy women's wear and other apparel.
It was banned, along with 59 apps, by the government citing the "threat to sovereignty and integrity" posed by these platforms.
However, Shein products were available in the online market through e-commerce platforms such as Amazon. The issues were also brought up at the Delhi High Court.

headline: Ecommerce, digital adoption to drive growth for Unicommerce Esolutions
content:
(This story originally appeared in
on Feb 03, 2025)
Unicommerce Esolutions
' growth in the coming quarters will be driven by ecommerce expansion through
digital adoption
, an increase in total addressable market from complementary offerings,
client acquisition
, and an extended
product portfolio
, the ecommerce software firm’s managing director and chief executive Kapil Makhija, said on Monday.
“The long-term outlook for the Indian ecommerce market is promising, driven by increasing digital adoption and evolving consumer preferences…We will continue to enhance our offerings further as per the needs of the ecommerce ecosystem,” Makhija told analysts during a post-earnings call.
The company currently offers three product platforms: Convertway, a marketing automation platform, Uniware, an order processing platform, and Shipway, a logistics management platform. A significant portion of profits will still come from the core platform, Uniware, while the company focuses on its two newer platforms for future growth, he said.
“Uniware, our flagship platform, has been the
market leader
in its segment with a large operating scale, and demonstrates strong operating leverage driving consistent growth in our profitability. Shipway and Convertway, on the other hand, are relatively newer entrants in their respective fields and we see significant potential for growth in their scale going forward,” Makhija said.
In November, the company had announced its acquisition of Shipway. Makhija said the first tranche of the acquisition was completed on December 17, with plans to acquire the remaining stake through a merger or stock swap.
Live Events
The company has over 7,000 clients including new-age consumer brands like omnichannel eyewear retailer Lenskart, homegrown wearable and audio product brand Boat, skincare brand
Mamaearth
and online fashion retailer Myntra.
It reported a 27% year-on-year (YoY) increase in its October-December
operating revenue
to Rs 33 crore. The Gurugram-based firm’s net profit for the quarter rose 62% on-year to Rs 6 crore, as it controlled expenses under various heads.
“Our flagship platform Uniware is quite stable, requiring only minimal investment, because we invested a lot on this platform during the year FY21 and FY22. Hence, our employee expenses are not increasing in line with our revenue growth,” Makhija said on the employee benefit cost came in at Rs 12.8 crore – down 11% YoY, and 20% lower sequentially.
“With our new product also nearing maturity, we are also realigning our manpower expenses to align with appropriate investments, resulting in expanding profitability,” he added.
Unicommerce, listed on the exchanges on August 13 at a hefty premium on the National Stock Exchange (NSE) at at Rs 235 per share, more than double its issue price of Rs 108.
In FY24, Unicommerce witnessed an increase in operating revenue, which jumped by 14.4% to Rs 103 crore from Rs 90 crore in FY23. The company reported a consolidated net profit of Rs 13 crore in FY24 compared to Rs 6 crore in the previous fiscal year.

headline: View: With extra money, consumers can upgrade from window shopping
content:
Budget
was like a well-cooked thali-a fine balance of flavours, keeping continuity while adding a few spicy new elements to match market realities. The larger vision of Viksit Bharat remained intact, and the finance minister has been handling the economic reins well-sometimes nudging MSMEs forward, sometimes giving the middle class a well-deserved push, all the while keeping the fiscal deficit beast in check.
Booster Shot
The Micro, Small & Medium Enterprises (MSME) sector, often the underdog in budget announcements, finally got the spotlight it deserved. The credit crunch was becoming as tight as Mumbai traffic, but the finance minister stepped in, clearing the way with enhanced turnover thresholds and credit guarantees.
More Money in the Gullak!
For years, the middle-class has been stretching its monthly budget like rubber bands on a fat wallet, hoping for some relief. This time, they finally got their due-a tax break worth nearly ₹1 lakh per taxpayer. With this extra gullak money, the great Indian consumer can now happily upgrade from window shopping to actual shopping.
Slow & Steady Wins the Race
Live Events
The FM continued with her slow-cooking 'dum pukht' approach-topping up successful schemes rather than introducing a full buffet of new ones. The India Post revival also made an entry, proving that sometimes, old is indeed gold. With its vast network, it can become a Swiss Army knife for logistics, banking, and e-commerce.
Move over Amazon, your friendly neighbourhood postman might just give you a run for your money! India's gig workers-
whether they are delivering your pizza or driving you home-finally got some recognition.
With over 10 million workers, this sector is the fastest growing employer.
Goodbye Red Tape
For those of us who lived through the Licence Raj, seeing compliance burdens ease is like watching the villain Amrish Puri turn a hero Rajesh Khanna. Less TDS/TCS complications, investor friendliness index, and a streamlined KYC registry-these are all steps in the right direction.
Final Takeaway-A Budget That Cares!
If past budgets were like strict parents telling us to save more, this one is more like a cool elder sibling saying, "Here's some extra cash go have fun, but don't go overboard!" The FM didn't just crunch numbers; she showed she understands the pain of the middle-class, the struggles of MSMEs, and the aspirations of gig workers.
So yes, this budget was like a good festival bonus-not flashy, but solid. More money in the piggy bank, more confidence in growth, and a clear message: the Indian economy is not just surviving, it's thriving!

Economic Times WhatsApp channel
)

headline: Reliance brings Shein back to India after 2020 app ban
content:
NEW DELHI:
Reliance Retail
has introduced Chinese
fast fashion
label Shein this weekend, almost five years after it was banned in India following diplomatic tensions between India and China. After a test launch on its fashion app Ajio for two months, Reliance has now begun selling Shein on an independent app available on AppStore and GooglePlayStore.
ET had first reported Reliance’s plans to bring Shein to India in its July 4 edition last year, and then in its December 24 edition about Reliance Retail test launching the
Chinese fashion label
in India.
Shein, now based in Singapore, is selling affordable fast fashion in India. Reliance Retail Ventures Ltd had signed a partnership with Shein two years back to sell its in India. Commerce and industry minister Piyush Goyal had said last month in a written reply in the Lok Sabha that at all times, an indigenous retail platform for Shein will be hosted with Shein having no access to, or rights over, data. He had also said that the ministry of textiles, after consultation with MeitY and the ministry of home affairs, had no objection to Reliance Retail’s proposal. Goyal had added that Reliance Retail Ventures Ltd has signed a technology agreement with Roadget Business Pte Ltd to develop an indigenous ecommerce retail platform, and stated that the platform would create a network of local manufacturers and suppliers to manufacture and sell products under the brand name Shein.
A report by consulting firm Redseer Strategy Consultants said that the Indian fast fashion market is expected to cross $50 billion in sales by FY31. The report added that the Indian fast fashion would make up for 25-30% of overall fashion retail by FY31 in the Indian market.
Shein has a presence in over 150 countries and over 250 million followers on social media, according to information on its website. The retailer reported more than $2 billion in profits for 2023 and close to $45 billion in gross merchandise value.

headline: Ambani's Reliance fielding Chinese giant to heat up retail showdown
content:
India’s fast fashion market is bracing for fierce competition. The soaring success of Zudio, a brand under Tata-owned Trent, has prompted
Reliance Retail
Ventures Ltd to collaborate with Chinese fashion giant
Shein
, which has gained global dominance, surpassing major fashion labels.
Reliance Retail has launched a dedicated app in India for Shein’s fashionwear under a licensing deal, nearly five years after its initial ban. According to Reuters, the app went live on Saturday without an official announcement from Reliance.
Also Read:
Ambani's Reliance brings Shein back to India after 2020 app ban
Reliance secured a partnership with Shein last year to reintroduce its fast fashion line in India. Shein was among the over 50 Chinese apps banned in June 2020 due to escalating India-China tensions.
Reliance
Retail had earlier initiated a backend test launch of Shein on its fashion and lifestyle platform, Ajio, marking the brand’s return to India four-and-a-half years after its government-imposed ban.
India’s Booming Fast Fashion Market
With brands like Zudio and Flipkart’s Myntra leading the segment, India’s fast fashion market is projected to surpass $50 billion in sales by FY31, according to a report by Redseer Strategy Consultants. Fast fashion is expected to account for 25-30% of India’s overall fashion retail sector by then. However, the industry remains highly fragmented, with numerous unorganized players vying for market share.
Live Events
Ambani's Chinese move to rival Tata
Ambani is leveraging Chinese-linked companies to challenge Tata in the fast fashion space. Trent Ltd., the retail arm of the $165 billion Tata Group, has seen its sales triple from pre-pandemic levels in dollar terms, while net profits have soared 12-fold. Zudio, its in-house fast fashion brand, has captivated young shoppers with trendy, affordable apparel. From just 80 stores four years ago, Zudio has expanded to nearly 560 locations across 164 Indian cities. The brand's success is driven by rapid inventory turnover in low-rent areas, allowing for high profitability despite slim margins.
In response, Ambani launched Yousta a year ago, positioning it as a direct competitor by offering all products under ₹999 ($12). However, the results have yet to materialize. Reliance Retail’s 8% year-on-year sales growth in the June quarter was primarily fueled by air-conditioners, refrigerators, TVs, and groceries, with fashion and lifestyle sales hampered by “tepid discretionary demand.”
Also Read:
Ambani is drawing on China-linked co's help in his battle with Tata
Shein’s Global Rise
The latest move marks a shift in Reliance’s strategy, which previously integrated brands like Superdry and Gap into its flagship Ajio platform. Now, Shein’s independent app will compete against Myntra and other fashion retailers.
Founded in 2012 by Chinese entrepreneur Chris Xu, Shein has expanded into a global fashion powerhouse, serving over 150 countries and amassing a social media following of 250 million. The brand generated more than $2 billion in profits in 2023, with its gross merchandise value nearing $45 billion.
Shein operates with a direct-to-consumer model, leveraging social media influencers and aggressive discounting to drive sales. Its portfolio includes brands like Romwe, MOTF, and Cuccoo. The company outsources manufacturing to around 5,400 third-party suppliers, mainly in China, allowing it to rapidly adjust production based on consumer demand. This efficiency has helped Shein maintain low inventory waste rates.
Also Read:
Inside the Chinese giant Reliance is fielding in its retail war
In September 2024, Shein became the world’s most-visited fashion and apparel website, surpassing Nike, H&M, and Zara, according to Similarweb data. Its transaction-making user base grew nearly 40% between January and August 2024, making it the fastest-growing international platform, closely followed by TikTok.
With a $66 billion valuation in 2023, Shein is now eyeing a listing on the London Stock Exchange.
Controversies Surrounding Shein’s Manufacturing Practices
Despite its rapid growth, Shein has faced criticism over its labor practices. A BBC investigation revealed that many of Shein’s factory workers log approximately 75-hour workweeks, violating Chinese labor laws. The report described relentless working conditions, with laborers stitching garments late into the night.
US political figures, including Senator Marco Rubio, have raised concerns over Shein’s alleged ties to forced labor, particularly regarding cotton sourced from China’s Xinjiang region. Amid these allegations, Shein is striving to improve its corporate reputation ahead of its IPO. The company asserts that it is investing heavily in compliance measures and fair labor standards.
Shein’s Return to India Under Strict Regulations
Reliance Retail’s
Isha Ambani
has played a crucial role in Shein’s return to India, ensuring that operations comply with local regulations. Under the agreement, Shein will act purely as a technology provider, while Reliance will retain full ownership and control over operations, including data governance.
Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal assured that all platform data would be stored in India, with no access granted to Shein. The agreement also mandates security audits by government-approved cyber experts. Additionally, Reliance plans to establish a network of local manufacturers to produce Shein-branded apparel, potentially boosting India’s textile sector and creating jobs.
Goyal clarified that while Shein-branded products were never banned in India, the app was. With its relaunch, Shein is poised to regain its foothold in the Indian market under Reliance’s watchful oversight.

headline: Budget 2025: 9 things you should know before your next shopping spree
content:
Finance Minister Nirmala
Sitharaman
announced several updates in her
Budget 2025
regarding the reduction in customs duties that could make various imported goods more affordable. Here’s a quick look at how these changes will benefit consumers:
Imported Jewelry Now More Affordable
Valentine’s Day shopping just got cheaper. A DeBeers platinum ring, previously priced at Rs. 2.50 lakh, will now cost Rs. 10,000 less thanks to a 5% reduction in customs duty.
Imported Beds and Mattresses on Sale
Sweet dreams are now at a sweeter price. An imported IKEA bed and mattress set, once priced at Rs. 65,000, will now be available for Rs. 63,725 after a 2.5% cut in customs duty.
Imported MacBook Pro Prices Drop
For those bringing back a MacBook Pro from a foreign trip, a price drop is on the cards. The laptop, which used to cost Rs. 3.46 lakh, is now set to cost Rs. 3.37 lakh with a reduced customs duty rate of 35%.
Imported Motorcycles at a Better Price
Imported motorcycles are now more affordable. A Kawasaki Ninja H2 750CC, previously priced at Rs. 23 lakh, will now be Rs. 1.64 lakh cheaper due to a 10% reduction in customs duty.
Imported Sofas at Reduced Prices
Imported luxury sofas are also getting cheaper. The Couch Potato leather sofa, which once cost Rs. 6.90 lakh, will now cost Rs. 6.76 lakh after a reduction in customs duty from 25% to 20%.
Historic Memorabilia Now More Affordable
Own a piece of history for less. A Mike Tyson-signed boxing glove, which was originally priced at Rs. 22,400, will now cost Rs. 19,400 following an 18.5% reduction in customs duty on items imported for personal use.
Imported Lighting Fixtures Now Cheaper
Brighten up your home with premium lighting. A "Lights of Scandinavia" LED chandelier, previously costing Rs. 2.33 lakh, is now available for Rs. 2.28 lakh due to a 5% reduction in customs duty on luminaries and lighting.
Solar Panels Now More Affordable
Embrace sustainable living for less. Installing solar panels on your rooftop is now cheaper, thanks to a 4% reduction in customs duty on imported solar modules.
Imported Interactive Flat Display Panels More Expensive
On the flip side, imported interactive flat display panels will now be costlier. The customs duty on these items has increased from 10% to 20%, making them less affordable for those looking to upgrade their home or office tech.

headline: Gen Z expands a new battlefield for retail giants
content:
A predominantly young population, expanding reach of social media influencers, the reels culture, and a new generation which is open to experimentation are fuelling growth in India's beauty and personal care market. Dozens of beauty brands have popped in the past few years even as global giants begin to find promise in India and Indian retail giants snap up smaller brands which pitchforked into prominence through e-commerce.
The beauty and personal care segment is also more or less immune to the widespread urban consumption slump. Consumers may cut spending on essentials but still buy their favourite beauty and personal care products.
As e-commerce democratises the beauty business, beauty and grooming products are fast filling up the online space with more than 3,500 brands, according to a
Redseer
Strategy Consultants-Nykaa report. Almost 96% of them operate primarily in the e-commerce space. “Many brands are being launched every year, enabling new consumers to enter the beauty and personal grooming category at different price points or upgrade as well,” Sharang Pant, head of commercial, tech and durables, NielsenIQ India, has told ET. “Online prices are cheaper by 10-30% versus offline for these products.”
The great Indian beauty boom
The Indian beauty and personal care market is poised to reach $34 billion by 2028, up from $21 billion now, driven by a surge in online penetration and a growing preference for high-quality, premium beauty products, according to a report by
Nykaa
and consulting firm Redseer. The online channel, as the fastest-growing segment, is expected to expand at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of approximately 25%, while the organised offline channel is anticipated to grow at 14%.
The ‘Nykaa Beauty Trends Report’, released a few months ago, noted that rising discretionary spending, fuelled by increased disposable income, expanded e-commerce access, and product innovation, are some of the other key trends driving momentum in this sector. Rising aspirations and higher incomes among Indian consumers will propel the market for premium beauty, expected to reach $3-3.2 billion by 2028, it said. Further, it highlighted a notable shift in consumer demand from personal care to beauty products in India, comprising skincare, makeup, haircare and fragrance categories.
Live Events
You Might Also Like:
How Gen Z is retouching the rules of the skincare market in India
A report by Redseer Strategy Consultants and Peak XV estimated last year that India’s beauty and personal care market will expand the fastest among comparable countries by size. The compounded growth rate is projected to be 10% between 2022 and 2027, which will take the market to $30 billion. India, expected to account for nearly 5% of the global growth opportunity, has a per capita category spending of $14, lower than China ($38) and a fraction of the US ($313). That is the definition of a big opportunity. For L’Oréal SA and Shiseido, two of the world’s largest cosmetics companies, India is a key growth driver.
Gen Z puts a gleam in beauty market
Besides the growing emphasis on self-grooming by the youth as they spend significant time on social media, putting up their photos and reels, a shift in consumer behaviour, especially driven by Gen Z, is shaping the beauty and personal care market in new ways. Companies selling cleansers, moisturisers, serums and lotions with claims of being backed by dermatologists, are now drawing a younger consumer base, especially Gen Z users who are influenced by social media celebs.
These youngsters are far more conscious of what goes on to their skin, compared to millennials and Gen X. They no longer chase basic whitening or moisturising creams. That translates to hyaluronic gel as sunscreen, kojic acid to treat dark spots and pigmentation, and snail mucin with peptide complex for smooth and moisturised skin. It is not just that they know what to buy. They have educated themselves on how each active ingredient works on their skin, even at the granular level of being aware of the exact percentage of ingredients used in products.
A key trigger for this shift has been influencers-turned-beauty gurus popularising such ware through
Instagram
and YouTube. “These ingredients may sound too chemical but consumers are now aware and seek transparency on what is being sold. In food, consumers look for protein, fat and carbs content on the pack to understand its benefits. Similarly, they want an honest approach for their skin care too,” Mohit Yadav, co-founder of
Minimalist
, which has been bought by HUL recently, told ET last year. “Even now, we are surprised by the level of knowledge consumers have compared to a few years ago when the skin care regime was much simpler,” he added.
Influencer marketing platform VHub.ai estimated last year that there are around 2,500 influencers on Instagram with more than a lakh followers, and nearly a dozen with over a million, all just talking about skincare. This number more than doubled over the past two years.
“This educational component, often delivered through relatable content and personal testimonials, has brought trust and credibility among followers, driving engagement and growth,” Sachin Modi, CEO at VHub.ai, told ET last year. There is also the quest for flawless, glass-like skin, propelled by K-beauty or Korean brands, and aided by K-pop and K-dramas.
“Earlier, there will be one shampoo, soap or cream which will come in the household, and everybody will use it,"
Varun Alagh
, co-founder of Honasa Consumer that owns personal care brand Mamaearth’s specialised skin care label The DermaCo, told ET last year. "Even the distribution channel was family oriented where one member would shop for the whole family. Also, the brands offered were limited,” he points out. “Now, brand availability allows you to express your individuality and hence, you would find that in each of the homes there are three different samples for different needs."
The Redseer report said micro-trends or short-duration fads of 3-6 months, especially among GenZ consumers, are also driving growth with products such as graphic eyeliners, tinted moisturisers, lip stains and colour-shift lipsticks becoming viral.
It’s the new-age brands that are really feeling the sheen as the ambassadors of this shift in consumer behaviour. Younger audiences find the relatability of new age brands higher compared to legacy players.
The beauty segment is shifting fast
India's expanding e-commerce sector has led to democratisation of the market and explosion of brands which is truer for the beauty and personal care segment. As e-commerce removed the high entry barriers which existed in offline retail and Gen Z opened up to experiment with new products as well as sought more personalised ones, India witnessed an explosion of beauty and personal care brands.
“Online platforms have become the preferred channel for purchasing luxury beauty products, with growth nearly double that of offline channels.,” Roosevelt Dsouza, head of customer success, FMCG, NielsenIQ India, has told ET. “This shift is driven by unique product offerings from small and mid-sized manufacturers, particularly on e-commerce platforms.”
The sudden growth in the number of e-commerce brands has led to new-age brands facing challenges on scaling up beyond a point or crumbling under the pressure to turn profitable. Many brands are now jumping onto the quick commerce -platform to tide over these challenges. However, consolidation has also begun in the sector as big brands have realised the power of personal connect with the consumer that small brands enjoy.
Recently, HUL, India’s largest FMCG company, announced the acquisition of a 90.5% stake in Jaipur-based direct-to-consumer (D2C) beauty brand Minimalist. The deal values Minimalist at a pre-money enterprise value of Rs 2,955 crore.
A leader in mass market brands, HUL is trying to capture growing demand for niche, premium beauty brands. This acquisition underscores HUL’s focus on premium, high-margin segments, aligning with parent company Unilever’s global strategy to tap into low-penetration categories. HUL has been reorganizing its beauty and personal care (BPC) division to sharpen its focus on premium offerings. Currently, this division contributes nearly a fifth of the company’s revenue and about a third of its profits.
Industry executives have told ET that various brands are looking at such options, but those conversations are in early stages.
India’s beauty market is becoming increasingly competitive, with focused brands like L’Oréal, Mama Earth, and Nykaa collectively holding 33% market share. This share is expected to grow to 42% by 2027, while traditional players like HUL and Procter & Gamble could see their share drop by 900 basis points to 58%, according to a report by Redseer Strategy Consultants and Peak XV Partners.
In 2023, the fast-growing market attracted India's India’s largest retailer Reliance Retail Limited, which launched its omni-channel beauty platform Tira, after the sudden rise of new-age brands Nykaa and Myntra. The
Tata Group
already has its beauty business called Tata Cliq Palette.

headline: Beauty and the ecommerce beast: As online breaks entry barriers, newer brands crop up, expanding offerings & market
content:
Kolkata | Mumbai: Indians are continuing to splurge on grooming, with
ecommerce
driving the boom.
The number of electronic device brands in India selling products such as hair stylers, straighteners, dryers and shavers online rose to 571 in 2024, from 399 in 2022, more than thrice the 154 sold in stores, according to market researcher
NielsenIQ
.
Beauty and
grooming products
are fast filling up the online space with more than 3,500 brands, according to a Redseer Strategy Consultants-Nykaa report. Almost 96% of them operate primarily in the ecommerce space.
“Online offers a wider assortment in the category,” said Sharang Pant, head of commercial, tech and durables, NielsenIQ India.
Live Events
Online up to 30% Cheaper
“Many brands are being launched every year, enabling new consumers to enter the beauty and personal grooming category at different price points or upgrade as well,” said Pant of NielsenIQ. “Online prices are cheaper by 10-30% versus offline for these products.”
The pace of unit or volume sales growth for electronic grooming devices online at 22% year-on-year is more than twice that in offline stores at 8.9%, showed data from NielsenIQ, which tracks actual sales.
On an already high base, the share of online sales to the total for electronic grooming products rose to 88% in 2024 from 84% in 2022, the researcher said. Industry executives peg the ecommerce market for electronic grooming products at over Rs 12,000 crore. In the beauty care segment, the online contribution has risen to 15% from 12% in the past year, according to NielsenIQ data.
Hindustan Unilever Ltd
(HUL), the country’s largest consumer goods company, pegs the total
beauty products
market at Rs 68,000 crore.
“The bedrock is wanting to look a better version of yourself,” said Harman Dhillon, executive director, beauty and wellbeing, HUL. “What ecommerce allows you to do is, it reduces the entry barriers that you had otherwise, in offline. Because it’s easier to get a product which is very, very specific and to list it, whether on your own website or to make it available is easier, versus, in the past, going in distributive trade and organised retail.”
The Redseer report said micro-trends or short-duration fads of 3-6 months, especially among GenZ consumers, are also driving growth with products such as graphic eyeliners, tinted moisturisers, lip stains and colour-shift lipsticks becoming viral.
The broader personal care segment is growing at 8.5% year-on-year, while the beauty category within that is increasing at 8.6%, NielsenIQ data showed. This is driven by premiumisation, innovative offerings, and the influence of global trends, such as the rising popularity of westernisation and South Korean beauty products and trends in India, the researcher said.
“Online platforms have become the preferred channel for purchasing luxury beauty products, with growth nearly double that of offline channels.,” said Roosevelt Dsouza, head of customer success, FMCG, NielsenIQ India. “This shift is driven by unique product offerings from small and mid-sized manufacturers, particularly on e-commerce platforms.”
The Redseer report said newer beauty care products are riding on trends popularised by influencers, pop stars and others, prompting consumers to shift from generic personal care to specific beauty products, such as the quest for “glass skin”, which first emerged in South Korea. This includes products such as sunscreen sprays and sticks, lip oil and lip tint, liquid blush, body butter, rosemary oil, salicylic acid serums and cleansers.
Shoppers Stop
,
FSN E-Commerce Ventures
(Nykaa) and others have said the beauty category is set to grow the fastest in recent earnings updates.
Nykaa
said its beauty vertical growth accelerated sequentially in the December quarter with revenue growth upwards of 25%.
Shoppers Stop chief executive officer Kavindra Mishra told analysts last week that beauty has “outgrown” overall business in the fiscal year thus far.
“With the launch of the latest version of ss.com app, our conversions have increased. In beauty, we have also launched same-day delivery from two stores. This is an experiment, and we are working on this project,” he said.

headline: CM Mohan Yadav invites Uniqlo brand to Madhya Pradesh; holds extensive talks with Japanese companies
content:
Chief Minister
Mohan Yadav
on Wednesday invited
Uniqlo
brand to Madhya Pradesh, as the state -- producer of very rare, unique naturally-coloured cotton -- went all out to woo marquee brands with its investor-friendly policies, availability of land and skilled manpower. Yadav also held extensive discussions on investment opportunities in
Madhya Pradesh
with Susumu Kataoka, Chairman of Japan External Trade Organization (JETRO) and his delegation at Minato-ku, Tokyo.
During the meeting, JETRO was invited by the CM to establish an office in the state, which is strategically located in the heart of India.
"JETRO stated that the upcoming 'Global Investors Summit' will be an excellent platform for Japanese companies to understand investment opportunities in Madhya Pradesh and strengthen partnerships. JETRO will assist in inviting more Japanese companies to the event and enhancing investment collaboration," the chief minister said in a post on X.
— DrMohanYadav51 (@DrMohanYadav51)
In a day packed with back-to-back meetings and wide-ranging dialogues, the CM interacted at length with the dynamic founder of clothing retailer Uniloq, Tadashi Yanai.
Live Events
Tadashi wants to replicate their model used with the US where they have involved smaller farmers in cotton farming and production. The CM welcomed him and Uniqlo brand into
MP
, expressing his eagerness for the association given that Tadashi is a well-respected name in the global business circles, and an deeper association will be mutually beneficial for both state and the brand.
Madhya Pradesh is also the only producer of very rare unique naturally coloured cotton in all of India. It has vast land farms, sound labour policies and peaceful labour unions, as well as good availability of water required for cotton farming.
Yadav also met Shohei Hara, Senior Vice President of the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), to discuss Japan's expertise in technology transfer, trade support, and youth employment initiatives in Madhya Pradesh.
"Our discussions focused on JICA's potential contributions to public and private sector enterprises in Madhya Pradesh, particularly in the areas of infrastructure and hydropower projects," the chief minister said in another post.
— DrMohanYadav51 (@DrMohanYadav51)
At Bridgestone headquarters in Tokyo, the CM also had an in-depth discussions with the Global CEO of Bridgestone Corporation, Shuichi Ishibashi, along with CEOs of various companies, with talks revolving around investment opportunities in Madhya Pradesh.
"I invited the officials to participate in the Global Investors Summit, which will be held in Bhopal on February 24-25, 2025. Madhya Pradesh offers immense potential in the automobile and tyre manufacturing industry, making it an ideal destination for industrial investment," the CM said.

headline: Offering ample opportunity for customers to recover unused gift card money, says Amazon
content:
Following Andhra Pradesh Deputy Chief Minister Pawan Kalyan's call for simplicity, transparency, and equity in recovering the balance of expired gift cards from e-commerce players, Amazon stated on Tuesday that it offers ample opportunities for customers to recover their money and adheres to RBI guidelines. Kalyan on Monday alleged that the process is seamless when it comes to adding money to an
Amazon gift card
but completely opposite when trying to recover money from an expired one.
He said users are compelled to contact customer service, explain their situation and go through a lengthier and complicated procedure, instead of the unused balance automatically going back to the linked bank account.
"Gift card issuer sends two reminders to the purchaser of the gift card before the expiration date. Even after the expiration, customers can simply and easily contact our customer care team for reactivation, if needed," Amazon said in a statement.
Besides adhering to the relevant regulations and guidelines of the RBI, Amazon said its
co-branded gift cards
can be redeemed on its e-commerce platform and across more than 10,000 apps for everyday use cases.

headline: Union Budget: Cashback and tax breaks for eco-conscious shoppers?
content:
Budget 2025
: The retail industry in India is positioned to make a big step toward adopting eco-friendly initiatives as the world moves more and more towards sustainable practices. A greener future can be ushered in by the government introducing policies that balance sustainability and profitability in the upcoming
Union Budget
2025–2026. To accelerate the integration of sustainability into mainstream practices, the brands in the retail sector are hopeful for the following potential policy considerations.
GST Reforms in Budget Favouring Eco-Friendly Products
Currently, India's Goods and Services Tax (GST) system does not distinguish between sustainable and conventional goods. Due to their higher production costs resulting from ethical sourcing and environmentally friendly procedures, eco-friendly brands often face competitive disadvantages. The government could consider encouraging producers and customers to adopt sustainability by reviewing the GST rates for eco-friendly products. For example, reducing the GST slab for sustainable products might not only lower their costs but also motivate companies to adopt greener practices.
Also Read:
Budget 2025 may use these modes to make consumer and retail dreams true
India Budget: Govt-Backed Cashback or Tax Incentives for Consumers
The government could also look at implementing tax breaks or reward programs for customers who buy certified environmentally friendly products in order to further promote the use of sustainable products. Policies like these could influence consumer behavior, similar to the incentives provided in sectors like electric vehicles. For example, customers purchasing products with recognized sustainability certifications could potentially benefit from a partial reimbursement of the purchase price. This would not only encourage eco-conscious choices but also raise awareness about the importance of supporting sustainable brands.
Also Read:
Sitharaman likely to give India’s ‘aam aadmi’ what they want?
Live Events
You Might Also Like:
Budget 2025: Will Sitharaman and co fuel India's luxe aspirations, premium growth?
Budget: Mechanisms to Provide and Monetise Carbon Credits
By putting in a place process to earn and monetize carbon credits, businesses can not only reduce their carbon footprint but also generate additional revenue. The government can help create a simpler, more accessible pathway for these businesses, thus promoting greener practices and enhancing India’s leadership in the sustainable retail space.
Also Read:
What the real estate sector is expecting from Union Budget 2025
Budget Expectations: Resolving GST Input Tax Credit Issues
The limitation on input tax credits under the existing GST system presents a problem for eco-friendly companies and adds to their financial burden, especially for small and mid-sized enterprises that use sustainable materials and methods. The government may give businesses investing in green practices much-needed relief by resolving these GST-related concerns. In addition to lowering costs, facilitating a more seamless flow of input tax credits, particularly between states, will enable sustainable companies to expand and increase consumer access to environmentally friendly goods. A smooth marketplace where green ideas can flourish and compete would be made possible by this action.
Budget and the Road Ahead
The government must develop workable policies in close collaboration with industry stakeholders in order to strike a balance between sustainability and profitability. To ensure effective implementation, clear guidelines , transparent timelines, and frequent evaluations are necessary. By prioritizing these initiatives in Budget 2025–2026, India has the opportunity to lead in sustainable retail, contributing to both environmental preservation and economic growth.
(The author Sudip Ghose is the founder and managing director of
uppercase
)

headline: E-commerce democratising growing luxe market, says Tata Cliq CEO
content:
Mumbai: The luxury market is experiencing growth with
affluent Indians
continuing to embrace
premium lifestyle offerings
, said
Tata Cliq
chief executive Gopal Asthana, citing strong revenue expansion at the company’s ecommerce platform for high-end products.
The platform,
Tata Cliq Luxury
, posted a 30% increase in revenue so far in fiscal 2025 compared with the year before, he said. As much as 55% of the platform's gross merchandise value in the ongoing financial year has come from
non-metro markets
like Jaipur, Chandigarh, Lucknow, Indore, and Nagpur, Asthana told ET on Monday.
The growth has been driven by strategic expansion into new categories. "We've seen significant momentum across several segments, including Indie Luxe (which sells luxury goods from India) and our beauty business, particularly in fragrances. Our home and footwear divisions have also shown strong performance. The recent addition of premium brands, such as the launch of the Bvlgari boutique, has provided further impetus to our business growth,” he said.
Ecommerce has been instrumental in democratising luxury retail across India, providing access to consumers in tier-2 to tier-4 markets who previously had to travel up to 800 kilometres to reach the nearest luxury store, Asthana said. The growth is particularly driven by HENRYs (high earners not rich yet), representing a new demographic of luxury consumers beyond the traditionally affluent.
"The luxury market is no longer limited to just the wealthy," Asthana said. "We're seeing strong demand from aspirational consumers who are increasingly seeking premium experiences and products like premium fragrance or sunglasses or a handbag in the range of Rs 25,000."

A report released by Tata Cliq titled "Thinking Beyond the Cart" identified 13 key trends based on year-long qualitative and quantitative analysis. The findings revealed that consumers are increasingly willing to invest in products and experiences that enhance their well-being and joy. The report also emphasised that personal attention and engagement are non-negotiable elements for premium and luxury brands. While the physical retail experience remains crucial in luxury shopping, its importance has become even more pronounced in the post-pandemic era. Sustainability and genderless fashion emerged as additional significant trends identified by industry experts.
The platform recently expanded its premium offerings with the launch of TimeVallée, a luxury multi-brand boutique, and Bvlgari's first digital boutique in India. The Bvlgari boutique offers accessories, including wallets, watches, and jewelry, with premium pieces such as kada bracelets retailing for up to Rs 12 lakh.
Asthana said when luxury brands like Bvlgari list on ecommerce, they are not just looking at discovery but also actual sales. "For a brand, it's extremely important to focus on sales. That’s why all our discussions with brands revolve around metrics like IPT (items per transaction), the number of impressions, CTRs (click-through rates) and add-to-cart actions. Some brands even request data on a weekly basis to gain deeper insights. They often compare this data with their ecommerce performance in developed markets, such as the US, to benchmark and strategise effectively."
Asthatna grouped luxury shoppers into three categories: those who are well-informed about a product and the brand; those who have experienced luxury in certain categories but are new to others; and those who are the aspirational customers who explore the offerings, engage with the business, and consider their options carefully. “To give you some indicative numbers, our average order value (AOV), excluding smaller, incidental purchases, is over Rs 10,000. While some categories see high volumes, our AOV remains consistently between Rs 10,000 and Rs 20,000."

headline: Demand for clothing, lifestyle goods remains weak; recovery uncertain
content:
The slowdown in demand for clothing and lifestyle products like televisions and smartphones, which brands initially believed was a temporary blip, is persisting even after two years.
Companies now say predicting a revival timeline is difficult as aggressive discounting strategies, including early end-of-season and
Republic Day sales
, have failed to boost demand.
With business growth remaining flat this Republic Day sales compared to last year, several companies expect a demand recovery only in the second half of 2025.
"People had bought what they wanted to buy by early December due to weddings and winter. Hence, sales in January are flat," said the CEO of a leading apparel brand company who requested not to be identified.
Live Events
Sales of discretionary items such as apparel, footwear and beauty started slowing in 2023 after two years of pandemic-induced runway growth.
According to the Retailers Association of India (RAI), sales growth in the organised retail segments such as apparel, footwear, beauty and quick service restaurants (QSR) was in mid-single digit last calendar year, compared to 15% in 2022.
"It's not that demand is not happening in the market but the growth rate of 7% is the new normal. So, the buoyancy of demand that we saw post pandemic is missing now," said Kumar Rajagopalan, CEO of RAI.
While sales of electronics usually peak during the Republic Day sale due to robust discounts run by the brands, there has been no major bump this year.
Electronics retail
chain Vijay Sales director Nilesh Gupta said volumes or number of units sold is flat as compared to last year and the challenges in smaller towns remain, with no pick-up in demand for entry to mid segment products. He said value sales went up by 5% due to premiumisation.
Brands said even online sales did not grow much in this year's Republic Day sales.
Republic Day and Independence Day are among the largest consumption periods in India, even though the festive season led by Diwali is the biggest.
Retail chain
Shoppers Stop
chief executive officer Kavindra Mishra said while the festive setup for Diwali was exceptional, November was slow, and December has been mixed for most of its peers.
"Inflation continues to be higher, which has tapered down in the last week.
Discretionary spending
has been lower and
consumer sentiment
, though it's better than last quarter...is nowhere near the pre-Covid or FY23 levels," Mishra told analysts recently. "In informal discussion with other peer members, there was a unanimous view that the last quarter (October-December) was lower than expectations, particularly considering the slowness we had in the first two quarters," he added.
Chief executives have flagged multiple reasons behind the consumption slowdown - high food inflation, low salary hikes, high debt by consumers, slowdown in new job creation, increase in housing rentals and home prices, and increased spending by a section of urban consumers on holidays.
Some companies are hopeful of a reduction in income tax rates in the upcoming budget to push consumption.
Electronic company
Havells
managing director Anil Rai Gupta told analysts last week that the first six months of the fiscal saw improvement in the consumer demand, but again, around Diwali season there was some weakness.

headline: Can Budget 2025 safeguard kirana stores from the quick commerce boom?
content:
India Budget
: The rise of
quick commerce platforms
in India is altering the traditional retail landscape. According to industry reports, these platforms, including Zepto and Blinkit, have grown at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 25 percent.
Their market share in the urban grocery segment rose to 8 percent in 2023, compared to 3 percent in 2021, Anand Ramanathan, Partner and Consumer, Products and Retail Sector Leader, Deloitte, wrote in a Budget note.
Tier 2 cities have emerged as significant contributors to this growth, according to Deloitte, accounting for 30 percent of the overall sales of quick commerce platforms. This trend highlights their expanding reach beyond major metropolitan areas.
The challenges facing kiranas
Kirana stores have faced significant challenges in FY25 due to the growing preference for quick commerce platforms, particularly in metropolitan areas. The rapid expansion of quick commerce platforms has adversely affected small retailers. The Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT) reported a 12 percent decline in revenues for kirana stores in urban areas.

Quick commerce giants leverage extensive funding, large warehouses, and expansive customer bases to offer heavy discounts, which brick-and-mortar kirana stores cannot match, the Federation of Retailers Association of India (FRAI) said.
This shift has coincided with a remarkable growth in India’s quick commerce industry, with its Gross Merchandise Value (GMV) surging from USD 0.5 billion in FY22 to USD 3.3 billion in FY24, a growth rate exceeding 280%, according to financial services firm Chryseum.
What shoppers want
The impact of this trend is evident in consumer behavior. A report by e-commerce consultancy Datum Intelligence in November highlighted that 82% of surveyed buyers shifted at least a quarter of their kirana purchases to quick commerce platforms, with 5% abandoning local stores entirely. The quick commerce market, projected to grow by USD 40 billion by 2030, has already contributed to a decline in kirana stores' market share from 95% in 2018 to 92.6% in 2023, with further reductions expected.
The concept of delivering groceries within 10 minutes has expanded to include products like healthcare items, electronics, clothing, and more. This expansion is drawing in consumers seeking convenience and speed.
The Datum Intelligence report revealed that 75% of online grocery buyers increased unplanned purchases in the last six months, with many spending over Rs 400 per order. “Nearly half (46%) of respondents report reduced spending at kirana shops, indicating a shift in customer behavior towards quick commerce platforms,” the report added.
Paresh Parekh, Partner for Consumer & Retail Sector at EY India, noted, “The rise of quick commerce in India has posed some unique challenges for traditional kirana stores by increasing competition for fast deliveries and convenience, potentially risking reduction in foot traffic.”
Technology-driven distribution models and faster fulfillment are key strategies enabling quick commerce platforms to outperform traditional stores, according to Elara Capital.
A helping hand in Budget 2025?
To foster equitable growth in India’s retail sector, Deloitte’s Ramanathan has proposed several policy recommendations to regulate quick commerce platforms. “This includes introducing compliance with FDI norms, fair trade practices and supply chain transparency,” he wrote.
These measures emphasise addressing predatory pricing, enhancing fund usage transparency, and ensuring compliance with existing legal norms. By implementing strict guidelines against predatory pricing, the market can be protected from distortions that disadvantage traditional retailers. Additionally, quick commerce platforms must be mandated to provide detailed disclosures on fund allocation, Ramanathan suggested, adding that they must also align their practices with Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) norms to maintain transparency.
Compliance with the Competition Act, 2002, and the Foreign Exchange Management Act (FEMA) is crucial to curbing anti-competitive practices. These legal frameworks should be enforced rigorously to ensure that quick commerce platforms operate fairly. Furthermore, a comprehensive ethical code of conduct is necessary to shield small retailers, Ramanathan wrote, adding that the government must “develop an ethical code of conduct that protects small retailers, distributors and kirana stores from market distortions caused by deep discounting and other anti-competitive practices.”
In December, FRAI urged the government to launch a dedicated platform for kirana stores to enable them to compete effectively. “Such support would enable the kirana stores to remain competitive amidst the increasing encroachment into their space by quick commerce companies like Swiggy Instamart, Blinkit, or Zepto,” said FRAI Honorary Spokesperson Abhay Raj Mishra.
India - a land of ‘couch potatoes’?
Union Minister of Commerce & Industry, Piyush Goyal, raised concerns about the growing popularity of online shopping in India back in August 2024, cautioning that it could potentially transform the country into "a nation of couch potatoes." He warned that the ease of e-commerce might encourage a sedentary lifestyle, with people choosing to stay indoors, watch OTT content, and order food online instead of participating in social activities.
While recognising the role of technology in enhancing consumer convenience, Goyal emphasized the importance of a measured and structured approach to e-commerce growth, given its potential effects on traditional retail sectors and the overall economy.
Highlighting the significance of social interactions, Goyal stated, "Going out for dinner or coffee with friends are essential for human development." He further stressed the need to evaluate the broader implications of e-commerce on sectors like local retail stores, pharmacies, and restaurants. "I'm not wishing away e-commerce—it's there to stay," he noted, urging a balanced and impartial analysis of its impact on various industries.
Budget 2025 as kiranas’ safety net
Experts believe the upcoming Budget 2025 could offer a lifeline to kirana stores. “With new technologies brought in by the government, like ONDC (Open Network for Digital Commerce), what is now required is a more focused approach in creating a specific solution for kirana stores that makes them as discoverable and accessible to customers, much like the way quick commerce companies are operating,” Mishra told PTI.
Suggestions for government support include incentives, simplified tax regimes, social security measures, and skilling programs. Parekh noted, “Kirana stores expect Budget 2025 to offer support including incentivizing partnering with quick-commerce platforms, say through policy etc, simplified tax and GST regime, social security and insurance, and skilling.”
India’s retail ecosystem, supported by over 30 million kirana stores and 8 crore small retailers, forms the backbone of the economy. Regulatory measures should safeguard their interests by creating mechanisms that facilitate fair competition with quick commerce platforms. Encouraging fair trade practices will help limit market concentration and promote diversity, ensuring that the retail sector remains competitive and inclusive.
As the quick commerce sector grows and reshapes consumer habits, Budget 2025 could prove pivotal in defining the future of India’s kirana stores.

headline: IKEA nails it! 90% deliveries in India via EVs
content:
IKEA
, the world's biggest
furniture retailer
, has said that opting to get their power from renewable sources not just helps the planet but has also helped their wallet, after the company saved nearly ₹100 million in electricity bills alone.
The company will accelerate its investments in India to drive its broader agenda-diversify its supply chain, build partnerships for local manufacturing and grow value addition from about a third to nearly half its portfolio, said Juvencio Maeztu, Deputy Global CEO, IKEA.
In a conversation with ET's Sruthijith KK on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in
Davos
, on Monday, he said even if investments in technology and materials for achieving sustainability goals could cause a conflict between short-term profitability and long-term sustainability, in the company's experience, it has always been proven right betting on the side of sustainability.
"In India we are doing home deliveries with EV trucks. It is 90% for the country, but it is already 100% in Hyderabad, Bangalore and Pune. We are proving that it is possible to be climate friendly and reduce costs at the same time," said Maeztu, adding that the company has made about 30% reduction in absolute climate footprint and at the same time, grown by 23.7%. In fact, energy efficiency and investments in renewables have saved ₹97 million globally for IKEA. He added that 100% of the energy used by the company on operations in India next fiscal will come from renewable sources. Half of Ikea's workforce in India across levels are now women, he said, adding that this diversity in the workforce was something the company was really proud of.
Local sourcing will not only create more employment but also secure more affordability while large volumes will also push technology enablement in India, which still accounts for just 1.5% of global furniture export. "That's why there is a big opportunity and IKEA is really aiming to develop much more sourcing in India. We are now in conversation with the government to align with international standards, the certification of the product," Maeztu, who counts a ₹100 meal with daal he once had in Amritsar as the best meal of his life. "I can still recall how good it tasted."
Live Events
IKEA started sourcing from India in the 1980s and has more than five dozen suppliers in the country, most of them in textiles. Over a decade ago, the erstwhile
Foreign Investment Promotion Board
(
FIPB
) had approved Ikea's Rs10,500-crore investment proposal to open 25 stores in the country by 2025. It has since opened three large-format stores in Hyderabad, Mumbai and Bengaluru-each large enough to fit about four football fields-and one smaller store in Mumbai.
It aims to open bigger stores in Gurgaon and Noida soon.
India is a key market for IKEA, and the company plans to increase its investments. "...we are not rushing for quick profit. We have come to India with a very long-term approach," he said.

headline: Kirana is too small to fail
content:
Quick commerce
can't disrupt India's retail sector beyond a point even though it is growing at a scorching pace. Global brokerage firm JP Morgan has recently maintained "Overweight" ratings on
Zomato
and
Swiggy
, the biggest quick commerce players. Mutual funds are estimated to have spent Rs 10,200 crore on buying Zomato shares in the last 3 months to make it the most bought stock in the December quarter.
Blinkit, Zepto, Swiggy Instamart and Flipkart Minutes are among the top quick commerce platforms in India.
A key highlight from the JP Morgan update is the significant expansion of dark store networks. Both Blinkit (owned by Zomato) and Zepto, another big quick commerce company, have surpassed their FY25 dark store targets, with Blinkit exceeding 1,000 stores and Zepto surpassing 700 stores in the third quarter of calendar year 2024 (3QCY24). Notably, Zepto currently holds a slight lead in the total number of dark stores. The expansion trend continued into December 2024, with dark store additions primarily occurring beyond the top 3, 5, and 10 cities, indicating a strategic push to penetrate smaller markets and expand the reach of quick commerce services across India. Both Swiggy and Zomato have recently raised money from the market to fuel expansion.
Also Read:
FMCG cos tailor price points for quick commerce to protect Kirana stores
With e-commerce majors Amazon and Walmart-owned Flipkart planning their own quick commerce services, the space is getting crowded.
Tata Group
too is planning its quick commerce venture. ET has reported that Walmart-backed PhonePe has become the first payments firm to try the quick commerce market. PhonePe’s
ecommerce
venture, Pincode, has fully pivoted to the quick model and now gone live with 15-minute deliveries in 10-15% areas of six cities.

Quick commerce companies quizzed by government over FDI, operating model
With growing competition within the space, the quick commerce business is expanding into ever-new territories. Major players have now forayed into services after transitioning from staples, groceries and FMCG to high-value goods.
A report by Bernstein says quick commerce is estimated to witness a 75% or more year-on-year (YoY) growth in 2025, outpacing traditional retail, which is projected to grow in the low teens. It is also expected to expand as tier-2 and smaller cities embrace this model.
Also Read:
Zomato infuses Rs 500 crore in quick commerce platform Blinkit
How quick commerce is eroding kirana business
The rapid growth of quick commerce has taken a heavy toll on
kirana
even as e-commerce players try to battle the impact on them. Quick Commerce has captured nearly half of kirana sales.
You Might Also Like:
A fast guy is pushing into omnichannel game. What can happen?
As consumer preferences shift towards the convenience of last-minute grocery deliveries, quick commerce companies are outpacing traditional retailers, with 46 per cent of consumers surveyed reporting a cut in purchases from Kirana shops, a report has said. The quick commerce market size is expected to reach USD 40 billion by 2030, a jump from USD 6.1 billion in 2024, according to the survey by Datum Intelligence conducted in October 2024.
Kirana stores, which historically dominated the Indian grocery market, are now facing an existential threat. The report showed that over 82 per cent of consumers have shifted at least one-fourth of their grocery spending from Kirana stores to quick commerce platforms.
Why quick commerce can't decimate the kirana store
Despite initial setback to kirana business due to explosive growth in quick commerce, the sector might ultimately prove to be resilient to the quick commerce onslaught. Kirana may survive the new retail war due to its unique business model.
ET has reported that consumer goods firms are reworking their channel strategies to protect neighbourhood kirana stores while also aligning them with changing shopping habits. The likes of Hindustan Unilever, ITC, Parle Products and Adani Wilmar have begun launching packs at different price points specifically for quick commerce - a trend that industry executives said will only gain traction. General trade accuses quick commerce platforms of eating into its business with predatory pricing and other unfair practices.
You Might Also Like:
India's e-commerce battlefield gets ready for bloody wars
Parle has launched separate packs of popular brands like Parle-G, Hide & Seek, Krack Jack and Monaco for quick commerce, priced Rs 50-100. The small biscuit packs, priced up to Rs 30, will be available only at kiranas, as per the ET report. Large retail chains such as
Reliance
and DMart, more popular for monthly shopping, will sell packs priced Rs 120-150. ITC has launched separate quick commerce packs for brands including Engage perfume, Savlon handwash and Mangaldeep incense. The country's largest packaged edible oil company, Adani Wilmar, is going to launch a separate brand for quick commerce for both cooking oil and staples like pulses. Hindustan Unilever, the leader in the consumer goods market, has also started to roll out separate packs.
The new strategy by consumer goods firms can pose a challenge to the breathtaking growth of quick commerce. It can make it difficult for quick commerce players to expand in the bottom consumer segment which prefers to buy small packs. While quick commerce can grow on the back of high-value purchases, increasing order size and diversifying into new services and product categories, its pace of growth will be retarded in the bottom segment where kirana will continue to rule.
Moreover, quick commerce players are coming under scrutiny on the pricing factor. All India Consumer Products Distributors Federation (AICPDF) has complained against quick commerce firms alleging that they indulged in predatory pricing and other anti-competitive practices. The complaint is now with the Competition Commission of India (CCI). Recently, a Bengaluru resident claimed a stark difference on a quick commerce platform in the prices for the same products, with iPhone users being charged significantly more than Android users. The country’s leading restaurateurs’ body may move the CCI against Zomato and Swiggy’s new standalone apps for 10-minute food delivery, ET reported based on sources a week ago. It claims the quick commerce companies are operating private labels for this service, which raises concerns for their restaurant partners.
In November last year, traders' industry body, the Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT), released a White Paper, accusing quick commerce platforms of misusing FDI rules to dominate suppliers, control inventory and fund predatory pricing.
Kiranas are also considering their own digital avatars. Nearly 80% of kirana stores losing business share to quick commerce platforms said that it is time they focus on digitalisation to compete with them in a survey conducted by Kiko Live, a SaaS solution for neighbourhood stores. It helps kiranas build their digital storefront on ONDC Network and give their store customers an online experience. Most of the survey respondents expressed optimism about the future, believing that transitioning to online and quick commerce platforms can help businesses grow within 1-2 years.
India has about 13 million kirana stores distributing grocery and daily essentials. They remain the backbone of FMCG companies especially in rural markets and in tier-2 and -3 cities. Many believe that both online and offline channels can coexist, and quick commerce and kirana will have their separate business turfs ultimately, with kirana continuing to cater to small-value customers and segments in rural areas and small towns where business will not be worthwhile for quick commerce players.
